sections.heading: ADT-1 Filing: Setting up an Auditor with ROC (MCA)
content: You can file ADT-1 online and let ROC know about the auditor's appointment. Stay away from penalties and not following the rules.
Under the Companies Act, 2013, ADT-1 is a required ROC filing that tells the Ministry of Corporate Affairs (MCA) about the hiring or re-hiring of a company auditor.
Compliance experts will make sure your ADT-1 is filed correctly and on time.

sections.heading: What is ADT-1?
content: ADT-1 is an MCA form that lets ROC know about:

points: Choosing or re-choosing a statutory auditor
Auditor chosen at an AGM or EGM

sections.heading: Legal Requirement
content: Filing ADT-1 makes sure that your business follows the law according to Section 139 of the Companies Act, 2013.

sections.heading: Late Filing
content: The Companies Act says that filing late will get you in trouble.

points: A fine for officers who don't pay their fines
Risk of ROC not following the rules
To avoid paying extra fines, it is very important to file your ADT-1 on time.
First appointment of an auditor (within 30 days of incorporation*)
Appointment of an auditor at the AGM
Appointment because of a casual vacancy
The Board does not need to file an ADT-1 for the first auditor appointment, but the AGM does.

sections.heading: What You Need to File ADT-1

points: Letter of consent from the auditor

sections.heading: Questions and Answers About Filing ADT-1

list.title: Do you have to do ADT-1 every year?
points: Yes. After every AGM, ADT-1 must be filed to hire or rehire an auditor.

list.title: Do you need ADT-1 for the first auditor?
points: If the first auditor is chosen at the AGM, then yes. The first auditor chosen by the board does not need ADT-1.

list.title: What happens if you don't file ADT-1?
points: The company could face fines and problems with ROC if they don't follow the rules.
